Exploring the Bioactive Properties of Z. Caribaeum The biological activities of plants are largely influenced by the presence and composition of secondary metabolites. These organic compounds, produced by plants for various physiological needs such as defense against herbivores, fighting diseases, or attracting pollinators, play a crucial role in their biology and interaction with the environment [ 38 39 Z. caribaeum Table 4 metabolites-15-00614-t004_Table 4 Table 4 Biological activities of metabolites from Z. caribaeum Compounds Family Biological Activities Plant Part Reference   Leishmanicidal Stem bark [ 32 Canthin-6-one ( 1 Alkaloid Trypanosomalactivity Stem bark [ 28   Antifungal activity Stem bark [ 40   Leishmanicidal Stem bark [ 32 5-methoxycanthin-6-one ( 2 Alkaloid Trypanosomal Stem bark [ 28   Antifungal activity Stem bark [ 40 Canthin-6-one-N- oxyde ( 3 Alkaloid Trypanosomal activity Stem bark [ 28 Chelerythrine ( 5 Quinolone Not specified Root [ 21 33 Skimmianine ( 6 Quinolone Not specified Root [ 21 41 Neoacutifolidine ( 7 Quinolone Not specified Leaves [ 31 Acutifoline ( 8 Quinolone Not specified Leaves [ 31 Acutifolidine ( 9 Quinolone Not specified Leaves [ 31 O-methylacutifoline ( 10 Quinolone Not specified Leaves [ 31 Acutifolidine palmitate ( 11 Quinolone Not specified Leaves [ 31 Umbelliforine ( 12 Coumarin Antiproliferative Root bark [ 18 Trans-avicennol ( 14 Coumarin Antiproliferative Root bark [ 29 6.1. Antichagasic Effects of Z. caribaeum Against Trypanosoma cruzi According to the World Health Organization’s (WHO) estimates in 2022, 6 to 7 million people were infected worldwide with Trypanosoma cruzi. 46 Z. caribaeum 1 2 N 3 1 1 Table 7 28 Ferreira et al. examined the trypanocidal activity of extracts from Z. caribaeum 1 2 In the in vitro test against the trypomastigote form, they found that the ethanolic leaf extract and canthin-6-one ( 1 1 Canthin-6-one ( 1 2 For the in vivo test, the authors showed that, at doses of 10 mg/kg, the ethanolic extract of Z. caribaeum 47 Bilbao et al. also examined the trypanocidal activity of chloroform extracts from Z. caribaeum 50 48 6.4. Antimicrobial Activities of Z. caribaeum The dichloromethane extract from the bark of Z. caribaeum Candida albicans Aspergillus fumigatus Trichophyton mentagrophytes 1 2 1 2 40 Table 8 1 2 40 The antifungal activity of the ethanolic extract of Z. caribaeum 49 Z. caribaeum 50 Ortega-Buitrago et al. explored antimicrobial activity using an in vitro test of the ethanolic extract of the leaves and bark of Z. caribaeum S. aureus S. mutans E. coli Morganella morganii Z. caribaeum S. aureus S. mutans E. coli M. morganii 51 In addition, Chaves-Bedoya et al. evaluated the antibacterial activity of ethanol extracts from Z. caribaeum Burkholderia glumae Z. caribaeum B. glumae 52 6.5. Acaricidal Activity of Z. caribaeum Nogueira et al. examined the acaricidal activity of Z. caribaeum Rhipicephalus microplus 53 Souza et al. also examined the acaricidal activity of acetone, ethanol, and methanol extracts from Z. caribaeum D. gallinae D. gallinae 34 6.6. Antimalarial Activity of Z. caribaeum Cebriàn-Torrejòn et al. reported the in vitro antimalarial activity of dichloromethane, ethanolic, and methanolic extracts of Z. caribaeum 14 1 2 P. falciparum 50 50 54 The antimalarial activities measured following [3H]-hypoxanthine incorporation were confirmed [ 54 Table 9 14 1 2 Z. caribaeum metabolites-15-00614-t009_Table 9 Table 9 IC 50 Z. caribaeum 54 Compounds P. falciparum 50 F32 K1 PFB FcB1 Trans-avicennol (1) 0.5 2.7 1.2 2.2 Canthin-6-one (2) 2.0 5.3 3.2 4.0 5-methoxycanthin-6-one (3) 10.4 5.1 Nt b Nt  Extracts DCM 8.9 8.9 Nt Nt EtOH 10.5 9.3 Nt Nt MeOH 89.5 >100 Nt Nt Chloroquine a 2.6 77.4 27.8 62.8 a b 6.7. Anti-Inflammatory Activity of Z. caribaeum In 2005, Márquez et al. evaluated the in vivo anti-inflammatory activity of the ethanolic extract of Z. caribaeum 25 Villalba et al. also evaluated the anti-inflammatory activity of hexane, ethyl acetate, and ethanol extracts of Z. caribaeum 55 6.8. Antiproliferative Activity of Z. caribaeum Cebrián-Torrejòn et al. examined the antiproliferative activity of a methanol extract of Z. caribaeum 14 14 29 6.9. Effects Against Cardiovascular Disease In 2017, Domanech-Carbo et al. showed how canthin-6-one ( 1 56 2+ 1 1 6.10. Larvicidal Activity In 2009, Sanabria et al. conducted biological tests on aqueous extracts of Z. caribaeum Aedes aegypti Z. caribaeum 57 7. Toxicological Aspects of Z. caribaeum Nogueria et al. conducted studies on the toxicological effects of essential oil from the leaves of Z. caribaeum Rhodnius prolixus 2 58 Cebrián-Torrejòn et al. also tested the toxicity in human fetal cells of dichloromethane and ethanol extracts, as well as canthin-6-one ( 1 14 Z. caribaeum 14 50 1 50 50 54 8.
